definitions.definition: watch over in order to protect or control.
examples: they were sent to guard villagers from attack by bandits
synonyms: policed "there is a guarded barrier in the mountains"

definitions.definition: watch over (someone) to prevent them escaping.
examples: his task was to help guard Japanese soldiers

definitions.definition: watch over (someone) to prevent them from escaping.
examples: police officers were guarding inmates who could not be accommodated in prison
synonyms: mind "the prisoners were guarded by armed men"

examples: farmers must guard against sudden changes in the market
synonyms: be on the alert for "forest wardens must guard against poachers"

examples: the company fiercely guarded its independence

definitions.definition: stay close to (an opponent) in order to prevent a good shot, pass, or drive.
a person who keeps watch, especially a soldier or other person formally assigned to protect a person or to control access to a place.
a body of soldiers serving to protect a place or person.
examples: the hound belonged to a member of the castle's guard

definitions.definition: the household troops of the British army.

examples: warden, warder, keeper; Morejailer; informalscrew; archaicturnkey "her prison guard"Morejailer; screw; turnkey her prison guard

definitions.definition: an official who rides on and is in general charge of a train.
each of two offensive players positioned either side of the center.
each of two backcourt players chiefly responsible for running the team's offense.
a device worn or fitted to prevent injury or damage.
a chain attached to a watch or bracelet to prevent loss.
a defensive posture adopted in a boxing, fencing, or martial arts contest or in a fight.
examples: this kick can curl around an otherwise effective guard

definitions.definition: a state of caution, vigilance, or preparedness against adverse circumstances.
examples: he let his guard slip enough to make some unwise comments
synonyms: wariness "he let his guard slip and they escaped"
